text: <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a unique member of the TRAF protein family because it lacks a RING finger domain and therefore lacks <extra_id_0> ubiquitin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ligase activity .

Accumulating data support a role for <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as both a negative and a positive modulator of NF-kappaB signalling by certain TNF family receptors , possibly in a cell-type - dependent manner [ 71 , 72 ] .

Expression of <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is inducible by <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and overexpression of <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibits <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB activation .

<extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient T cells are hyper - responsive to <extra_id_0> TNF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , with enhanced proliferation and activation of the NF-kappaB signalling pathway .
<extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also functions as a negative regulator of <extra_id_0> CD40 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced NF-kappaB activation .

<extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - deficient dendritic cells , however , show attenuated responses to secondary stimulation by <extra_id_0> TRAF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - dependent factors , suggesting a positive regulatory role in these cells .
The mechanism by which <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> modulates NF - kappaB activation is still unclear .
Most probably , <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> competes with TRAF family members for binding to the receptor or other signalling proteins .
Alternatively , <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might recruit <extra_id_0> A20 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> with which it can physically interact [ 73 ] .

A genome-wide association study examining more than 300 , 000 SNPs among approximately 1 , 500 autoantibody - positive RA cases and 1 , 800 controls identified a genetic variation at the <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - complement component 5 locus as an important RA risk locus [ 74 ] .
Subsequent work indicates that <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is more likely to be the causative locus [ 75 ] .
Recent work in a Korean population also demonstrates genetic association of the <extra_id_0> TRAF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> region with RA [ 76 ] .
